Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Non-Line of Sight Geolocation Using Massive MIMO Antenna Arrays
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is to pinpoint a mobile device with greater accuracy to aid in emergency situations. The technology will focus on improving geolocation accuracy of mobile devices in rich scattering environments, where current technology suffers significant degradation. In some situations, the location accuracy in these degraded environments results in first responders unable to locate the emergency sufficiently fast, costing lives. The geolocation technology uses the large antenna arrays expected with the onset of 5G and leveraging the attendant rich scattering environments to enhance the location accuracy of current techniques. This level of geolocation accuracy will lead to many new commercial applications, such as augmented reality and autonomous vehicles.


This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will prove the technical feasibility of the non-line of sight geolocation technology. There are multiple aspects of this project well-grounded theoretically, but requiring demonstration as well as research in algorithms to both improve the performance of the solution and decrease the necessary processing power. The first area of research is RF phenomenology of: 1) the ability to rely on far-field models; and 2) clustered multipath models. The second research area is deconstructing a multipath channel to its individual ray components accurately enough to represent the true electromagnetic reflections, then using that derived information for geolocation. The goal of this project is to advance the technology to proof-of-concept demonstration of both the RF phenomenology and the non-line of sight geolocation algorithms. This will be accomplished through algorithm development in simulation environments and further validated with over-the-air experimentation. It is expected that RF phenomenology models will be refined in this process and fed back into the simulation environment.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Multipath-enabled Geolocation (MpeG) technology provides more accurate and robust geolocation by exploiting reflections observed in a received wireless signal. While traditional geolocation techniques like Time Difference of Arrival degrade in the presence of reflectors or obstructions in the environment, MpeG technology uses the reflections of the electromagnetic wave in order to improve the geolocation. The recent emergence of large antenna arrays coming with 5G and other systems is a motivating factor to move to this approach. Large antenna arrays, which typically contain more 16 or more antennas, allow for high precision resolution of angle and time of arrival of the individual multipath components of the electromagnetic wave onto the antenna array. SPT’s MpeG technology has the potential to improve geolocation accuracy wherever reflections exist in a wireless system.

Although the technology applicability is broad, we have developed a targeted solution to improve geolocation in cellular networks, leveraging the deployment of large antenna arrays coming with 5G. The MpeG technology will be integrated in the base station equipment as a network-based geolocation technology, where the geolocation estimate is produced in the network equipment rather than on the device side.

Geolocation has been or is being woven into the fabric of nearly every industry from Public Safety to healthcare, from shipping, warehousing and manufacturing to automobile navigation and safety, from online shopping to targeted advertising. But as with any technology the more we rely on it, the more we expect of it and there are now significant gaps in its performance and availability. There is one very powerful technology that has not yet been applied, and that technology is based on the uptake of large antenna arrays by ceullar service provides, coupled with powerful learning-based digital signal processing algorithms. MpeG requires no changes to the wireless device. It has virtually unlimited accuracy in both horizontal and vertical dimensions. It extends availability of accurate geolocation into buildings and other challenging situations. As a result, it will save more lives when applied to public safety, health and vehicle safety, save businesses more money when applied to shipping, warehousing and manufacturing, and save consumers time and effort when shopping. These are just a few of the more obvious applications. 

Our first target application is autonomous vehicles. Because MpeG is a network-based technology, it works by estimating the location of the vehicle using the cellular signaling and then transmitting that estimate back to the vehicle. The vehicle can then combine it with its other onboard sensors to produce an updated estimate or choose between multiple sources based on their relative confidence. With current semi-autonomous vehicles, MpeG technology would allow the vehicle to drive unassisted in more environments than it previously could. For fully autonomous vehicles, MpeG technology may be one of the key enabling technologies that would allow full autonomy.
